subject: Vaildation!?--or not!
author: Frank Sumption
full_text:
--_85f1db66-281e-4509-b086-97a317cf662f_
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


 
 Well that was a bust, sending a voice to a site in the UK that claims t=
o be scientific, and been investigating since the 80s. I sent the "What She=
 Said" voice, and they can't hear it, so it's not valid. We all know how su=
bjective these voices are, not everyone can hear them, and most don't hear =
the same thing. I think this is just another way of debunking, claiming to =
be scientific, but not being open enough to allow one the hear anything. I =
did tell them about rooms of people hearing the voices, but that seems to h=
ave been ignored, as well as the TAPS article. It was interesting that they=
 are in Europe (UK) and heard the voice as German sounding, but I guess tha=
t doesn't count for anything either. 
 
 Frank-S
 
 
 
 
 
It=92s an intere=
sting approach but there do seem to be obvious problems. If you are going t=
o scan radio frequencies, you will get different relative station strengths=
, depending on where you are geographically (as a radio ham, you=92ll appre=
ciate this). This means that results will be highly inconsistent from place=
 to place and time to time, depending on local reception conditions. Also, =
given enough attempts, you will inevitably sometimes get whole phrases that=
 may seem meaningful. I can=92t see how you can differentiate between the o=
ccasional random accident and genuine messages.
 
I listened to your =91Wha=
t she said=92 clip many times but I can=92t really make much out. It sounds=
 like =91wit dee fassing ding=92 to me. In fact, given the accent, I=92m no=
t sure it=92s even English, sounding more Germanic or Scandinavian to me. 
=

 Well that was a bust, sending a voice to a sit=
e in the UK that claims to be scientific, and been investigating since the =
80s. I sent the "What She Said" voice, and they can't hear it, so it's not =
valid. We all know how subjective these voices are, not everyone can hear t=
hem, and most don't hear the same thing. I think this is just another way o=
f debunking, claiming to be scientific, but not being open enough=
 to allow one the hear anything. I did tell them about rooms of people=
 hearing the voices, but that seems to have been ignored, as well as the TA=
PS article. It was interesting that they are in Europe (UK) and heard =
the voice as German sounding, but I guess that doesn't count for anything e=
ither. <BR>

 Frank-S<BR>
